content.title: Angle of Elevation vs Depression
content.body:
1. Line of Sight: The line drawn from the eye of an observer to the point in the object viewed.
2. Angle of Elevation: The angle formed by the line of sight with the horizontal when the object is above the horizontal level.
3. Angle of Depression: The angle formed when the object is below the horizontal level.

content.instruction: When dealing with the Angle of Depression, remember this rule:
content.exactPhrase: The Angle of Depression from a point to an object is numerically equal to the Angle of Elevation of the point from the object. This is because horizontal lines are parallel, making them alternate interior angles.

content.title: Which Ratio to Use?
content.body: In 90% of Height and Distance problems, use Tangent (tan) because they involve Height (Opposite) and Distance (Adjacent). Use sin only if the Hypotenuse (ladder length/kite string) is mentioned.
